title: 103_hr5255
content: The "Thomas Alva Edison Sesquicentennial Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes Thomas Edison's contributions as an inventor and plans to commemorate the 150th anniversary of his birth in 1997. Edison's inventions, including the light bulb and phonograph, revolutionized civilization. The "Thomas Alva Edison Sesquicentennial Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of 750,000 $1 silver coins to honor Thomas A. Edison's 150th birth anniversary. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. The silver for minting will be sourced from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins minted under the "Thomas Alva Edison Sesquicentennial Commemorative Coin Act" should be emblematic of Thomas A. Edison's inventions. Each coin will bear a designation of value, inscriptions of the years 1847-1997, and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The obverse of the coin will feature the likeness of Thomas A. Edison, and a design competition will be held for the obverse. The design for the coins minted under the "Thomas Alva Edison Sesquicentennial Commemorative Coin Act" will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee through an open design competition. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility starting January 1, 1997, with minting authority ending on December 31, 1997. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, a surcharge of $10 per coin, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount on sale prices. SEC. 8. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. The Secretary shall promptly pay the first $7,000,000 of surcharges from coin sales under this Act as follows: \1/7\ to the Edison Birthplace Association in Ohio for endowment, \1/7\ to the Museum of Arts and History in Michigan for a special museum on Thomas A. Edison, and \1/7\ to the National Park Service for preserving historic documents at Edison's "invention factory" in New Jersey. The Secretary shall allocate funds from coin sales under this Act to various institutions for the preservation and expansion of Thomas A. Edison-related programs and museums in different states. The Secretary allocates funds from coin sales to support Thomas A. Edison-related programs and museums. Excess surcharges go to the National Numismatic Collection at the National Museum of American History. The Comptroller General can audit organizations receiving payments from the Secretary. SEC. 10. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
